Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Tests of Large Scale Cosmology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This program will study the clustering properties of galaxies with the primary goal of testing dark energy models. "Dark energy" is the name given to the mysterious cause of the accelerating expansion of the universe. Broader impacts include training of graduate students. In addition, the PI will work on improvements and extensions of the existing Sloan Digital Sky Survey-IV Plates for Schools program. The simulation and mock catalog tools developed will be publicly released and have application to other science investigations using several existing and future spectroscopic sky surveys. The software developed for the analysis of multiple dark energy and modified gravity models will be publicly released.

The investigators will use eBOSS galaxy survey data and produce mock galaxy catalogs to examine 3D clustering statistics with goals including distinguishing among dark energy models, testing statistical homogeneity with the observed large-scale structure, improving systematic weights, and improving the realism of mock catalogs by including tidal fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this proposal was to use galaxy redshift survey data to better understand our universe. Galaxy redshift surveys create maps of the large scale structure of the universe. Analyses of these maps inform us as to the nature and evolution of the universe. These maps are one of the primary tools for understanding the accelerated expansion of the universe. Our program was both to assess what current data says about theoretical models of accelerated expansion, and to provide tools to better use these data by created “mock” galaxy redshift surveys.

The redshift survey our team focused on was the Extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (eBOSS), part of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV. This survey used different types of targets to map out cosmic structure at different epochs. Luminous red galaxies were used as tracers of the cosmic density field 6 Gyr ago. Emission line galaxies were targeted to make maps of the universe at 8 Gyr ago. And quasars were used to make large-scale maps of the universe at 10 Gyr ago. The analysis of these maps requires a robust estimate of the statistical and systematic uncertainties in the measurements created from them. Our team provided such tools to the eBOSS collaboration using the “Quick Particle Mesh” method of making mock-ups of the various eBOSS maps, providing many thousands of possible eBOSS surveys.

This grant supported NYU GRAs Zhongxu Zhai, who is currently a postdoctoral scholar at Caltech, Sicheng Lin, who is scheduled to graduate in Spring 2021, and NYU postdoctoral researcher Mehmet Alpaslan. Zhai collected all available cosmological data to perform a comprehensive survey of current theoretical models of cosmic acceleration, determining which—if any— of these models could be currently ruled at and what future data will enable. Zhai also performed the small-scale clustering analysis of the eBOSS LRG sample and used these results to create QPM mocks for the LRG catalogs. PI Tinker created quasar mocks used in the first analysis of eBOSS quasar clustering. Lin created the QPM mocks for the ELG sample. These mocks were used in the final analysis of the eBOSS survey. PD Alpaslan extended the QPM method so that it could be applied at any epoch and with any type of tracer of cosmic structure, regardless of whether it is a small star-forming galaxy or a massive early-type object. Thus, the QPM method can be used as a tool not just for eBOSS but for any future survey.
